act_title: Act Three: The Terminators
speaker: nadia reiman
utterance: Gene Hamilton writes back to the White House official, defiant, cc-ing all the bosses at DHS, quote, "I don't think we agree with that path." The White House doesn't write back. Less than an hour later, Gene sends another email to the same White House guy and caves. Hi again, he says. We will pull back, though, he says, many of the concerns are, quote, "entirely overblown and completely irrelevant."

act_title: Act Three: The Terminators
speaker: nadia reiman
utterance: The next day, the Department of Defense weighs in. A foreign affairs specialist sends an email. It begins, "It has been brought to our attention," and the tone of utter disapproval never lets up. She says the Sudan memo is wrong about conditions in Sudan. That armed conflict is ongoing. It's not safe for Sudanese to return there.

act_title: Act Three: The Terminators
speaker: nadia reiman
utterance: She says what they've written is, quote, "a clear departure to past DOD messaging on Darfur to our Congressional committees and foreign partners." She says the Department of Defense would appreciate being included in any policy discussions that impact Sudan.

act_title: Act Three: The Terminators
speaker: nadia reiman
utterance: There are more emails after that, and in the end, Gene Hamilton does make a small concession. A few sentences get added back to the Sudan memo. But the result is still the same. TPS for Sudan is ended. The new guard wins.

act_title: Act Three: The Terminators
speaker: nadia reiman
utterance: One by one, the countries in these emails lose TPS. After Sudan comes Nicaragua. Soon it's El Salvador, Nepal, Honduras. The administration ended up terminating TPS for 98% of the people who had it.

act_title: Act Three: The Terminators
speaker: nadia reiman
utterance: I talk to government officials who've dealt with TPS, and they all said TPS was messy. That it was something temporary that became permanent, and it probably shouldn't have. But at the same time, an enormous number of people are currently living here on TPS. Over 400,000. Most of them have been here legally for almost 20 years.

act_title: Act Three: The Terminators
speaker: nadia reiman
utterance: Inevitably, a whole new life grows out of two decades of just being somewhere. People start businesses, buy houses, get married, have kids. And these kids, the sons and daughters of TPS recipients, US citizens, they're part of the lawsuit that released all these emails. They're suing the government over this very mess so their parents aren't sent back home to a place that isn't their home anymore.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Nadia Reiman. She's one of the producers of our show. Act Four, IRC You, Now You Don't. The President has cut the number of refugees officially allowed into the United States from 110,000, under the previous administration, to 45,000. But in fact, in this fiscal year, they're not even going to bring in that many people. Just 22,000 will arrive. That's the smallest number ever in the history of the refugee program here.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So a bunch of these refugee settlement offices that are around the country are going to be shutting down. Our producer, Zoe Chace, was there for the final days of one of them in Garden City, Kansas.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: I flew into a tiny airport. Garden City is southwest Kansas, the middle of the plains. Oklahoma's right below us. Colorado's not far west. Amy Longa was waiting there at the airport. She started the office four years ago for the International Rescue Committee. She told me I'd recognize her, and I did. The only black woman there. Straight back, tall, and a bright turquoise African print dress.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Everyone recognizes Amy. I'll find out soon then even Amy refers to herself in the third person a lot. Like, she'll say, everybody knows Amy. I can't get away because it's, like, Amy, Amy, Amy everywhere I go.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: And truly, like, the kid at the Hertz counter called out to her. Amy, have you seen this? And handed her a flyer for some kind of Hertz deal. It's like the character Amy plays in this town is bigger than Amy actually is.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: It's Tuesday, July 24. The office is supposed to close on Friday. I follow Amy in my rental car and when I get there, the office looks wrecked. Cardboard boxes, an abandoned paper shredder, an old car seat. I mean, it looks closed. But Amy's in the middle of a meeting, in Arabic.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: She and one of her clients are sitting in two office chairs pulled up near the door. Where you'd expect a desk between them, they're just knee to knee in these rolly chairs. The client's name is Eltahir. He's from Sudan. He's apparently asking Amy to help him figure out why he got his federal tax refund, but not his state one. Amy takes the papers he brought. Says she'll look into it.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: OK. Now, are you comfortable leaving this with me and we make appointment tomorrow?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: What do you want to do? I can't-- [NON-ENGLISH SPEECH]

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: I'm looking around at this abandoned office and Amy and I'm like, what? Appointment tomorrow?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: OK. So why are you still having these conversations if you're going to be closed in two days?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: Because technically, the office is still open. The office is open.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: You're the only one here.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: I am the only one. And I'm here.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Yeah.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: I'm supposed to have packed all these. And I-- it's difficult to pack when you still have to answer these questions.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Refugee resettlement is exactly what you'd imagine, if you've ever thought about it. You do a bunch of interviews overseas, go through a major security screening process. You fly to the United States, someone meets you at the airport and takes you to your new home.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: The US government funds a sparse apartment with food that's culturally relevant, like food that will be familiar to you, as well as cash assistance, housing assistance. This lasts for three months while you look for work and go through some cultural orientation. And all this is managed by a resettlement agency, a nonprofit that contracts with the State Department to do this stuff.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: In Garden City, it's the International Rescue Committee, the IRC. They help you get a social security card, figure out your health insurance, find a job, go learn English. Pretty much all the things that make up a life here. Three months. 90 days. I do wonder how they came up with that. Making a whole life in 90 days.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: The IRC office works with their clients for up to five years with some government assistance. Most of Amy's time is spent with clients far longer than 90 days. This guy from Sudan, he's been here two years. This office is being closed because so few refugees will be relocated here in the future. But the fact is, Amy is right in the middle of these relationships, and she has to cut them off.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: The people who are resettled here have a never-ending range of questions. For instance, this is Edie. He came to Garden City recently via a refugee camp in Tanzania. He's Congolese. He's a very giggly guy, but I think it's nerves.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: He comes in, sits down with Amy, and unfolds a paper with four questions on it. One is about a guy not calling him back with a job. Another is about a bank card. How do you use it? He didn't have a pin number. Didn't know what a pin was. She activates it.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: Activated.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: man
utterance: Thank you, madam. [INAUDIBLE] now. It was good.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: There's a church question, a health insurance question, then he thinks of two more.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: man
utterance: Another question now please. Sorry.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: It's like this all the time. How do I get a birth certificate for my new baby daughter? How much does it cost? How is my green card application doing? Do they need more information? Is my boss racist? Then why isn't he responding?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: How much is it to go to the dentist? Should I pull this tooth out of my mouth? If I pull the tooth, should I replace it with a new tooth or leave the gap? And what will people around here think if I have a gap? Is that bad? Where is the dentist's office?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: One night, Amy's meeting with this guy at his apartment. And when she's done, this other guy, who's not even a client, runs after her and yells at her from a balcony that he needs to talk. And she's got three days left in this job, but she makes an appointment with him, too. And again, I'm like, why are you meeting with this guy? Like, where is he going to sit even?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: He walked out of that house. I'm sure he knew-- we were in the sitting room. He knew the IRC is there, or Amy. And as we moved out, he got out to the balcony and said, I'm going to take this chance and ask. If it was not something important, he wouldn't have pushed the button that far.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Amy has this ability where it's like she imagines all the thoughts in their head. She can picture the entire thought process of the person who's sitting in front of her.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: He just didn't jump out and run. He chewed it. He digested it.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Mm-hmm. That's your problem, I think. You can imagine everybody's reality too closely.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Amy has been a displaced person. First from Uganda, then to Sudan. She ended up in Khartoum. Then she had to flee Khartoum. Then back to Uganda where she was displaced again, until she went to college in the capital city Kampala. Then she worked for the UN, then she came to the US.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: When Amy's office closes on Friday, Edie and the others will still have somewhere to go. They're getting hooked up with a local branch of Catholic Charities, a nonprofit that stepped in to fill this gap, to close out the 90 days of whoever's left. They've never done this work before, though, so it's been kind of trial by fire, more people than they expected.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: And they admit, they don't offer the suite of services and care that the IRC does. And they do not have caseworkers who were themselves displaced people in Africa.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: When I talked to them, they copped to that. Yes, it's been hard. And no, we do not have the unique instinct of Amy Longa. So it's going to be different. Edie, who comes here at least three times a week, wants to know how to reach Amy after the office closes.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: No, I'm not giving you my cell phone number and I cannot give you my address. But Garden City's small. I can guarantee you we will meet somewhere.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: There was this one meeting I saw Amy have with a client that I will never forget.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: Hey. How are you, bubba?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: This kid, Norkamal, he's just a kid, really. 19 years old. He's Rohingya Muslim from Myanmar. The Rohingyas have been brutally persecuted there. He fled to Bangladesh, then Malaysia, then he came to the United States not being able to speak.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: It's almost like he has no vocal cords at all. He's injured. I don't know how or why. Like, he really can't talk. He talks like this. Like, if you just made a K sound at the back of your throat. It's a whisper. (WHISPERING) "Ka." He also can't read much or write at all.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Nor and Amy have gotten very close this year. It's almost like a mother-son relationship. Nor wants to get a surgery, a risky surgery, that could bring his voice back. He has health insurance, but it still took him a year and a half working in a beef slaughterhouse to save up $6,000 for the co-pay. Except, of course, his consultation with the doctor is for August 1.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: August 1. the day after Amy's office closes, when she's no longer technically supposed to be working with them. Though, of course, she'll still be his contact with the hospital. It's taken them all year to perfect their communication, and it's intimate watching them. It's kind of a lip reading, and signing, and looking into each other's eyes. He shows her some medical records she told him to find.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: You kept it together. I think this is it. You see, it's from the hospital in Malaysia.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: They sit cross-legged from each other on the floor. Amy's desk was literally just pulled out from under her. Some guys came and picked it up as a donation.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: Let's give it to the doctor, OK? Don't open it. Don't put anything in it. This is for the--

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: That's him saying, "the doctor."

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: When?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Wednesday.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: amy longa
utterance: Wednesday. Perfect. Bingo.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Amy's clients. Lots of them non-English speaking, unskilled labor job having, expensive surgery booking. This is where the immigration debate lives. President Trump's idea, the idea of America First, it kind of means fewer people like this. Why can't we take care of the people in America first?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Trump supporters have said that to me for years now. That they think refugees take American jobs. They cost taxpayers too much money, these government grants to resettle refugees. This county in Kansas went 63% for Trump, so I figure a lot of people here like his policies. I found one of them on Facebook being skeptical of refugees. Then I found her in real life--

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: All right. Let me come a little closer.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: --in a farmhouse just past the meatpacking plant. She and her husband were sitting in their garage watching baseball, drinking beers, throwing the cans into the corner.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: OK. So who are you, sir?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: My name's John Becker.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: OK. And Mr. Becker, what do you make of this refugee resettlement office closing?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: I don't even know what it is.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: OK. So you know refugees come into Garden City, Kansas, right?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: Refugees?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Refugees.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: What does that mean?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: OK. What's a refugee? A refugee is like, basically, they've been-- they're coming from a war-torn country. Somalia, the Congo, Sudan, stuff like that.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: I don't buy that. I don't believe that.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: OK. Well, I'll just tell you the definition of it first and--

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: I don't believe that.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: OK. And they get vetted extensively.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: I don't believe that either.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: You don't believe the vetting thing.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: No. I don't believe they're vetted either.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Right. Well, I guess the distinction that I just do want to make, though, is that they are here legally. It's not illegal immigration. You know, they have permission to be here. They're flown over here by the UN and State Department.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: Why are they doing that?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Well, because, you know, they're refugees. They can't go home.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: Why can't they?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Because their home is unsafe.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: Oh, I don't buy that. I don't believe that either.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Why don't you believe it?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: I just don't believe all that stuff.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: John Becker is not the first person I've met who wants a moratorium on refugees. He is the first one who doesn't seem to believe in them, like they're unicorns or elves.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Well, it seems to me that now that they're closing down the office, there'll be fewer refugees here. Somebody is seeing things the way you are.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: So there's going to be few of them? Fewer?

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Yeah.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: Oh, well, I applaud that.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: It's the Trump administration.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: john becker
utterance: We don't want to change our whole society here just for a few refugees. We don't want to do that.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: mrs becker
utterance: They can go to a bigger town, bigger city maybe.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: They come here to change our culture. That's how the Beckers see it. Not to state the very, very obvious, but this is the opposite of Amy. Whereas she imagines their lives and needs, to the point of anguish sometimes, he doesn't believe they actually exist. He can't imagine their lives.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Garden City has train tracks, and grain silos, and enormous wind turbines. It has cows in a field under a big metal sign that says Eat More Beef. It smells of shit around 4:00 in the afternoon. You can smell it at the Walmart parking lot.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: But whatever politics that evokes for you, I believe most of the city doesn't agree with the Beckers. Of the people in town I found who wanted the office to close-- six-- 2/3 of them were Beckers. Their relative had been killed on a motorcycle by a Somali.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: The county that Garden City is in is not majority white anymore. There are taco spots everywhere. There's a Vietnamese grocery store. There's a Somali neighborhood. And the IRC office, in a way, acts as the glue between these two parts of town that are coming together.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: My impression is that most people in town don't want the office to close at all. People like the chief of police, who loves Amy, loves the IRC office. They worked together particularly closely when the Somali community here was threatened by a bomb plot by white militia guys outside of town. The local hospital works closely with the IRC. So do the local schools.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: The Beckers complain newcomers aren't assimilating fast enough. John Becker said a few times, why don't they want to be Americans? But they very obviously do. That's why lots of them are in the IRC office day after day, like wide-eyed kids on the first day of high school. Help me figure out how to fit in. And that's what the IRC office helps them do.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Close the back of the truck.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: The moving company has just finished packing up the truck and slams the back door shut. They're driving all the files to Wichita, where the lone IRC office in the state remains. We watch them drive away, cart off the whole office that she founded four years ago.

act_title: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don't

speaker: zoe chace

speaker: ira glass

And the best way to explain this story-- when Zoe was at the IRC office in Garden City, one of the refugees-- the guy at the beginning of her story, Edie-- he asked her at some point, like, why is this happening? Why are so few refugees coming in that this office has to close?

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And at the time, Zoe actually didn't really understand why. Like, why were only 22,000 refugees arriving in the United States if 45,000 was the number that the administration set for itself? And she looked into this, trying to figure it out. And to understand the answer, you have to go back to this promise that the President made back when he was a candidate. You remember this one.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: donald trump
utterance: Donald J. Trump is calling for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States until our country's representatives can figure out what the hell is going on.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So the President acted on this campaign promise in his very first week in office with the travel ban, right? He banned travel to the United States from seven countries. But that was not all it did. It also shut down the refugee program. Like, the refugee program from all countries all over the world. It was, like, a total and complete shut down for 120 days.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: ira glass
utterance: The idea is shut it down for 120 days while the administration figured out what the hell was going on. In other words, how we vet refugees that we resettle in this country. And at the end of 120 days, theoretically, the refugee resettlement program was supposed to start back up again.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: ira glass
utterance: But then something weird happened. Refugee resettlement, it never really started back up again. Not full force. Look at the numbers. Take Iraq, which is not on the President's travel ban list-- the final one. Last year, we let in 6,886 refugees. This year, 130.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: ira glass
utterance: OK. How come? Like, what happened? They went through a process, they came to a conclusion, they fixed their thing. Should have start started back up. What happened? Zoe searched around and found somebody who actually knows.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Back when Donald J. Trump said he wanted to know what the hell was going on, what he meant was, what's the vetting process for how we figure out who gets to come in? He didn't trust what was already in place. So when he announced the travel ban, the White House pulled together people from across the agencies. Homeland Security, the State Department, National Counterterrorism, Intelligence. All the people you'd want in a room like that.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: And one of the people in the room was Barbara Strack. She was the chief of refugee admissions for USCIS, USCIS being a Department of Homeland Security that handles immigration. She remembers their first meeting on day one of 120.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: We met in a large conference room that was really full with people around the table and people against the wall. And--

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: It was a lot of people.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: A lot of people.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Barbara says the way most people in the room were looking at it was like this. The refugee program is already incredibly rigorous. It's months, sometimes years, of interviews, data collection, security checks.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: The people in the room were, like, we think of this as very safe. But OK, let's do better. Let's make what we already think is extreme vetting more extreme. It was a real A team. The top people. Barbara says everyone was on the same page.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: Our goal is that this program is up and running again on day 121. So we need to be very organized. We need to meet quickly and get the program through the other side when there can be confidence again.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: I talked to three other officials who are involved in the 120-day group, two who still work in government, and they all felt like Barbara. Let's put our back into it, focus, hit the target. So they do it. They meet, they divide into subgroups, they write up a report that makes a bunch of recommendations, which are classified.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: My impression from Barbara and the others who worked on this was we implemented every improvement we could imagine to a process that was already tight. And the final conclusion of this group of experts was if you institute these improvements into the process that we already have, for sure, it is safe to turn the program back on. So go ahead. Start admitting the refugees again with the more extreme vetting that you wanted.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: And then, on about 110 of the 120 days, they hear back from the White House. The White House did not like the conclusion of this review. And according to Barbara and the others I spoke to in the group, the White House wanted it to change.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: They had expressed concern about the recommendation to resume refugee processing of all nationalities.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: And do you know which nationalities the White House was worried about?

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: I'm trying to think if there's any reason not to say this on the record. There's probably not. I was told that there was particular concern about Somali nationals.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: The administration specifically pointed to Somalis as the sticking point.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Why?

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: I don't know.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: What do you think?

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: I honestly can't speculate.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: You don't want to speculate.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: No, I honestly-- to this day, I don't know.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: And there's no rationale that you were given? Like, because Somalia is like this or like that.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: The rationale wasn't shared with me.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Two government officials confirmed this for me. Somalia wasn't the only concern, they said, but it was a major concern. It was chief of staff John Kelly, in particular, who was unhappy, they said. I think it was bullshit, one guy in the group told me. At the end of the day, the data didn't show that Somalis were any special risk.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: So after 120 days, the White House reopened the refugee program for some countries, but not for a handful of countries who make up a lot of the refugees that are resettled here. For Somalia and 10 others, including all the countries in the original travel ban, the refugee program would stay suspended. For them, the 120 day review got another 90 days.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: My boss asked me to think about options for how to address the White House's concerns.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Barbara says she and the other members of her group were sort of at a loss for what else they could possibly review. But they went back to work. They came up with some more recommendations. After 90 days, in January 2018, the White House did restart the whole refugee program. But it was like turning on a faucet and nothing coming out.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: If you look at Somalia and those 10 other countries, this fiscal year it looks like we will admit 3% of who we allowed just the year before. Last year, we admitted more than 6,000 Somalis. This year, just 250. The extreme vetting has gotten so extreme, it seems, that few people can actually get through it.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Barbara says the changes they recommended shouldn't have had this effect. It shouldn't have slowed things down so much. Others I spoke to from the group said the same thing. It's not clear why the numbers are so low, but Barbara and the other people I talked to said the White House just never supplied the staffing and the resources to carry out the new vetting.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: A few people told me that the FBI, in particular, isn't staffed up enough to do the checks it's supposed to do. As a result, there's not a ban in place on these refugees, but the outcome is nearly the same.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: A DHS spokesperson said the new screening procedures are undoubtedly making America safer. They point to one specific example. An Iraqi wanted for murder in Iraq who entered the United States through our refugee program in 2014. They said today, with the new vetting procedures, he would not have made it through.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: There is some risk with every immigration program. If you wanted a zero-risk immigration system, you wouldn't have any immigration at all.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: barbara strack
utterance: My sense is that the risk tolerance of this administration is very, very low with regard to the refugee program. You know, approaching zero.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Barbara thinks, though I believe DHS would deny this, that they just want a different kind of refugee coming in, if any come in at all. She and another staffer told me about various times going up to the Hill to talk about the refugee program to Congress back when Jeff Sessions was a senator.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: Do you vet for culture? he asked. Another time she saw someone else who's now a Trump official, Gene Hamilton, for a briefing. Do you screen for integration potential, Hamilton asked, the ability to assimilate? No, she said.

act_title: Act Five: Why So Few
speaker: zoe chace
utterance: That's something we've always taken pride in, actually, as a country, she told him. The standard for refugee resettlement has always been vulnerability. How much can we do for you, not how much you can do for us.

act_title: Credits
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Zoe Chace. Again, remember, this story is our secret. Don't tell anybody who heard the radio show. OK.

act_title: Credits

People who put together today's show included Zoe Chace, Dana Chivvis, Neil Drumming, Hillary Elkins, Damian Grave, Michelle Harris, Chana Joffe-Walt, David Kestenbaum, Seth Lind, Anna Martin, Miki Meek, Ben Phelan, Robyn Semien, Alissa Shipp, Lilly Sullivan, Christopher Swetala, Matt Tierney, Julie Whitaker, and Diane Wu.

act_title: Credits
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Our Senior producer is Brian Reed. Our managing editor is Susan Burton. Special thanks today to so many lawyers. Erica [INAUDIBLE], Nicole Ramos, [INAUDIBLE], Bob [INAUDIBLE], Jennifer Walker Gates, Miriam Ackerman, Morgan [INAUDIBLE], Ana Maria Schwartz, Anastasia Tonello, Edna Yang, Steven [? Navar, ?] Rebecca [INAUDIBLE], Francisco [INAUDIBLE], Crystal [INAUDIBLE], Sandra Feist, Emmy McLean, Teigen [INAUDIBLE], Andy [INAUDIBLE], Rebecca Brown, Rebecca Press, and many others at Central American Legal Assistance.

act_title: Credits
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Also [INAUDIBLE], Robbie Grammer, Ben Kestling, Mark O'Brien, Marcy Smith, Katie [INAUDIBLE], Eric Schwartz, Sarah [? Kraus, ?] Jennifer [? Sine, ?] Mary [? Giovanolli. ?] And a bunch of government spokespeople, including [INAUDIBLE], Michael [? Bars, ?] and [? Devin ?] [? O'Malley.

act_title: Credits
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Our website, thisamericanlife.org. This American Life is delivered to public radio stations by PRX, the Public Radio Exchange. Thanks, as always, to our program's co-founder, Mr. Torey Malatia. You know, he keeps inviting me to this little vacation house he has. And whenever I ask him, like, what is it like? He's so vague. He's just--

act_title: Credits
speaker: nadia reiman
utterance: The country conditions are what they are.

act_title: Credits
speaker: ira glass
utterance: I'm Ira Glass. Back next week with more stories of This American Life.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: Remember when the news was boring, and politics was boring? That happened, right? I'm not imagining that. You were there. I was there. That happened in our lives. I miss it. I didn't appreciate what a good thing it was when we had it.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: I don't know about you, but me-- I've spent a full week obsessively reading about Judge Kavanaugh, and watching videos online, and calling people to discuss it. And I know this is just daily life in our totally divided country these days, but can I say, for me-- again, for me-- of all the moments we've had these last few years where red America and blue America look at the exact same event and come to radically different conclusions-- to me, this one feels the worst.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: I think because the original hearing itself with Dr. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh-- the testimony was just so long. It was so many hours. And then both witnesses were so emotionally raw that even watching it was emotional. It was upsetting. And then since that hearing, we've had this week of waiting for the FBI report, which held us all for a week in that same state of agitation and disbelief-- Republican disbelief at the Democrats, Democrats' disbelief at the Republicans. But even in moments like this one, there are people who haven't picked a side.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: And incredibly, sometimes, those people are the ones who have to decide. They have to cast a vote in the United States Senate. And it does not seem fun for them.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: Today on our show, we have somebody in that situation in our first act-- Arizona Senator Jeff Flake. In our second act, we leave Washington behind. We have somebody who's literally deciding on a man's life or death, with no real experience or understanding of how to do it. Both those people, having to make these huge decisions-- they are not comfortable at all.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: From WBEZ Chicago, it's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. Stay with us.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: Act One. Judge.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: So Senator Jeff Flake was one of the central players in the drama on Capitol Hill this last week. Turn on the TV and you'd see his tortured face. He dragged his decisions down to the wire over and over. He was undecided, then seemed like a no on Kavanaugh, then was a yes, then was a let's wait a week. It was Jeff Flake who made the Senate wait for a new FBI investigation. Then he was a yes again.

ep-658.speaker: ira glass
ep-658.utterance: Our producer, Zoe Chace, has spent a lot of time with Jeff Flake over the last year. You may remember the hour-long episode she did, recording him for months as he tried to pass some kind of DACA bill. And she was with him in the days before and after the Kavanaugh hearing, watching what he was going through and talking to him about how he made his choices. Here's Zoe.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: The first thing I want to talk about is the elevator. It's a big story-- how Jeff Flake changed his mind because two women accosted him on an elevator. I'm here to tell you that's not a true story. That's not what changed his mind.

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: Look at me when I'm talking to you! You're telling me that my assault doesn't matter!

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: I was there, right behind the women yelling. That's why my recording isn't as clear as what you heard on CNN. I'm just staring at Flake, peering out from the elevator. He had just stood me up for an interview.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Jeff Flake's face can be a little deceiving. He looks kind of miserable a lot of the time when inside, he's just humming a little tune. In this case, though, I think he was miserable. He had just released a statement saying he was going to vote for Kavanaugh. He had dashed right past a bunch of CNN reporters, and around the corner to get to the elevator, to get to the vote. And now he was stuck.

ep-658.speaker: woman 1
ep-658.utterance: You are allowing someone who is unwilling to take responsibility--

ep-658.speaker: woman 2
ep-658.utterance: Ma'am, I'd be happy to take you--

ep-658.speaker: woman 1
ep-658.utterance: --for his own actions--

ep-658.speaker: woman 2
ep-658.utterance: Talk-- ma'am?

ep-658.speaker: woman 1
ep-658.utterance: --to sit in the higher court of the country.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: And then he went to the meeting, where he asked for an FBI investigation for one week.

ep-658.speaker: man 1
ep-658.utterance: And what they said in that elevator door appears to have led a US senator to change his mind. Their words have now reverberated around this country.

ep-658.speaker: man 2
ep-658.utterance: Flake had declared that he would be voting for Kavanaugh's nomination. Then he was confronted by a mob of screaming protesters, the youth wing of the Democratic Party. Jeff Flake crumbled.

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: Archila was one of the two women in that confrontation with Senator Flake. Good morning.

ep-658.speaker: archila
ep-658.utterance: Good morning.

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: When that elevator door closed with Senator Flake, did you think that history might change?

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Archila and Maria Gallagher-- the other woman at the elevator-- they always hedge how influential they were. But lots of others don't. I'm reading things like, it was the elevator pitch that altered the trajectory of American history. An online site, "Support the heroes who convinced Flake," raised over $30,000 in a couple days.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Lots of people love this version of events, and I think it's because they just want to believe protest works. So much of these last two weeks has been people watching the same stuff on TV, and seeing what they want to see. Here's how I know that story about the elevator, about how it changed Jeff Flake's mind, is not true. First of all, I saw him shake his head no when asked about it by other reporters.

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: And did the women who confronted you this morning, did they have any role in changing your mind?

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Also, we talked about it.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: That wasn't the thing. It was a thing.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: It was a thing-- just not the thing that convinced him. Protesters don't affect him like that. I've seen him confronted by protesters over the health care bill, the tax vote, the Dreamers. And for days now, the Capitol building has been choked with them. They're stopping senators as they move through the halls-- sometimes chanting, sometimes telling horrific, very personal stories of sexual assault.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: It's everywhere, and it's a lot. Just the day before, Flake and I got in an elevator on the other side of the building. He was in the middle of a story about Lindsey Graham.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Lindsey pulled me aside last night.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Women jumped on the elevator with us. They wore "be a hero" T-shirts, and "I believe women" T-shirts. They were filming him and calling out, "Do you believe women, Senator Flake?"

ep-658.speaker: woman 1
ep-658.utterance: Do you believe them? Do you support women?

ep-658.speaker: woman 2
ep-658.utterance: We support women.

ep-658.speaker: woman 1
ep-658.utterance: Do you believe women?

ep-658.speaker: woman 3
ep-658.utterance: We support women.

ep-658.speaker: woman 2
ep-658.utterance: We support women.

ep-658.speaker: woman 3
ep-658.utterance: We believe women.

ep-658.speaker: woman 2
ep-658.utterance: Do you believe women?

ep-658.speaker: woman 1
ep-658.utterance: Thank you. Thank you.

ep-658.speaker: woman 2
ep-658.utterance: We believe survivors.

ep-658.speaker: woman 1
ep-658.utterance: Senator Flake? What do you have to say? Please? Do you have something you can say to women right now, and the survivors?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Glad we're having this hearing today.

ep-658.speaker: woman 3
ep-658.utterance: Yes.

ep-658.speaker: woman 1
ep-658.utterance: Are you going to do the right thing?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: I'm glad we're having the hearing.

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: Because it's not your body!

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Does it affect you when people yell at you like that?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: The benefits of being shallow.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: That's Flake making fun of himself. We've talked about this before. Like lots of men his age, he doesn't connect too well to emotions.

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: John McCain would have done the right thing.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: And he walked into the hearing to listen to Dr. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh, not sure what to do.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Before I explain what happened next, I want to just say, going into a day like this undecided is both very rare for a senator, and very rare for everyone in America right now. I don't think being undecided could have been more scarce that day. Think about it. Do you know anybody who didn't already know who they would believe, and who they would not? The one time he spoke in the hearing, he sounded just as unsure as he had going in. And it was at the end of the day.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: This is not a good process, but it's all we've got. And I would just urge my colleagues to recognize that, in the end, we are 21 very imperfect senators trying to do our best to provide advice and consent. And in the end, there is likely to be as much doubt as certainty going out of this room today. And just have a little humility on that front. So thank you.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: If you watch the news, you know at least the outlines of what followed. But just to explain-- because I think you can't understand what happens at the end with Jeff Flake unless you know what happens here-- the night after the Ford-Kavanaugh testimony, Thursday night, Flake stays up all night, freaking out over what to do. Some close friends told him about their own sexual assaults. He talked to advisors. He talked to lawyers, going over what was said.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: He found Ford credible and convincing, but he came back, over and over, to the fact that there was nothing corroborating her testimony. No one else could put him in the room that night. He found Kavanaugh credible also, and his anger wasn't as off-putting to him as I thought it might be. His staff said they'd never seen him like this.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: It was agonizing, I have to say. It really was-- more so than anything, any decision, on a vote. I've had debates with staff, and discussions late last night, too. And it was pretty raw, you know?

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: The next morning, of course, Flake finally releases the statement. He's going to vote yes on the judge.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Whatever you do, they say, in the end, you've got to come back to presumption of innocence.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: He goes to the elevator, gets yelled at on TV, then to the committee meeting. You know that part.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Meanwhile, Chris Coons, Democratic senator from Delaware, is on his way to the meeting with a bunch of reporters. And he gets the news that Flake's a yes. He chokes up, reportedly, says, "Oh, fuck," and then, "We each make choices for our own reason. I'm struggling. Sorry." A lot of tears in the Capitol those two days.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: The meeting begins. The two sides rail against each other. Flake's stressing, gets up and makes a call. He probably checks Twitter, because he usually does. But he says he did not see how viral the elevator video was going, and the bad PR of it. He says he wasn't thinking about that at all.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: So he comes back. And then Coons gives a speech at the committee meeting that he said was directed at one man-- Jeff Flake. They're actually friends. They're on the Foreign Relations Committee together. They've been all over Africa together, too. And they have breakfast almost every week at the prayer breakfast. Coons is Presbyterian, Flake reminds me, while he's a Mormon. And there was something very Presbyterian, he said-- just unadorned and practical-- about the way Coons was speaking.

ep-658.speaker: chris coons
ep-658.utterance: And I will say, briefly, at the outset, that before yesterday began, I prayed. I prayed for Dr. Ford and her family. I prayed for Judge Kavanaugh. And I prayed for all who would watch yesterday, uncertain whether we could conduct ourselves respectfully.

ep-658.speaker: chris coons
ep-658.utterance: I know since the day that my Democratic colleagues and I learned of these allegations, we've had one consistent request-- to allow the FBI to investigate them in a nonpartisan, professional, even-handed manner, and deliver their findings to us so that we could reach a conclusion.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Flake and I talked about that moment on the phone.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: That it had an impact, and the biggest impact, I'm sure. That is far more accurate than this narrative out there that it was the protesters that moved it.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: That day at the meeting, Flake gets up, walks across the room, taps Coons on the shoulder, and they're on their way to a deal. Later, he explained what was going through his head.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: I wasn't at peace with where I was. And when I got over there and then saw the food fight-- just resumption of yesterday's-- I said, we can't-- I can't do this. I know how this is being viewed out there, that people see this rush to judgment, and as Republicans move through and not look at the facts, and just try to get this done as quickly as possible-- and that's not good. It's not good. Long term, look what it does to the institution, it's just horrible.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Preserving the integrity of the process on the Senate Judiciary Committee is a much less romantic story than the one about two survivors of sexual assault changing a senator's mind at the last second. That's what happened, though.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: And finally, that day, the world sees Jeff Flake find a third way. It's something he's been looking for for a long time on a lot of issues-- a way to vote with his Republican colleagues, but stand for certain principles with the Democrats. It's the weirdest niche. But he's a weirdo right now-- a ghost Republican. He doesn't really have a constituency he's speaking for, being anti-Trump but pro his policies.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: He's retiring from the Senate in a few months. As he says, he could never have done something like this if he were still running for office. There's no value to reaching across the aisle, he says. There's no currency for that anymore. If you do that, you'll lose. So there is not much crossing over to the other side ever, by anybody-- which is maybe why, when you do cross over, this is what happens.

ep-658.speaker: man
ep-658.utterance: How you doing, Senator?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Doing well. How are you?

ep-658.speaker: man
ep-658.utterance: Good for you, man.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Thanks.

ep-658.speaker: man
ep-658.utterance: God bless you.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Appreciate it.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: This is the consequence-- New York City loves Senator Jeff Flake. I know, because the day after the committee vote, I picked him up at Penn Station and got him a taxi.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: But I also called a car.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Oh, you did?

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Yeah.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Oh, well don't.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Because I was like, the Senator? I don't know if he wants to wait in a taxi line. I don't know if that's a thing you're used to doing.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Yeah, I'll be all right.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: No Capitol police protection, no staff-- just me, and a lot of new Jeff Flake fans.

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: Could we take a picture with you?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Sure. You bet.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: I end up taking pictures for them.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Do you think they know that you're going to vote for Kavanaugh?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: I don't know. I think that will all go away if I do.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: 86th and Central Park West.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: I don't know. I think people are so starved for any sign of bipartisanship.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: I'm going to go ahead and say bipartisan, in New York, means you agree with the Democrats.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: This is all happening because on my way back to New York from Washington on Saturday, I ran into Chris Coons on Amtrak. He told me Flake was on the Acela right behind us. That Flake had invited himself, along with Coons, to the Global Citizen Concert at The Great Lawn in Central Park, broadcast live on MSNBC. I can't think of a bluer place, to be honest-- a more on-the-nose location for the hashtag resistance.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: So I'm surprised to hear Flake's coming too, and I text him to see if I can go. He gets me credentials, and I take him uptown. I get a little lost. Because I'm from here, I think I know where everything is, but I don't. And then we're running across the 86th Street transverse.

ep-658.speaker: man
ep-658.utterance: Senator Flake? Good work.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Thank you.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: New York loves you, Senator Flake.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: And we head to a little trailer backstage to meet up with Chris Coons. Outside, tens of thousands of people are already out on the lawn. These two senators are going to deliver a short, impromptu speech about bipartisanship to this crowd.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Can I ask you who's performing before them, and who's performing after?

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: Cardi B.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Cardi B?

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: Is after.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Is after?

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: Yeah.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: You guys are the opening act for Cardi B. I don't know if he knows who Cardi B is.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: This is where Flake's reaching across the aisle gesture gets epically surreal-- and it's hard to top how surreal the week has been already. All these famous people keep popping into the trailer.

ep-658.speaker: robert di niro
ep-658.utterance: What you did-- you're a hero. And it's so funny that other people don't know how simple it is to be a hero.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: It's Robert Di Niro, who steps to Flake with a finger in his face, like a scene from Goodfellas.

ep-658.speaker: robert di niro
ep-658.utterance: We rely on you. Too much had gone down with this guy. He's got to go. I know it's because they want the midterms, and this, and that. But we're beyond all that. We're beyond all that.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: It's weird to hear Robert Di Niro say the word midterms.

ep-658.speaker: robert di niro
ep-658.utterance: I'm telling you, you're a hero, man.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: John Legend.

ep-658.speaker: john legend
ep-658.utterance: I appreciate what you all did this week. And we just know that we're all watching and hoping that you make the right decision for the country. OK? That's all I'm saying. [LAUGHTER] You know how I feel about it.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: The director Ava DuVernay.

ep-658.speaker: ava duvernay
ep-658.utterance: So thank you so much for listening to women.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Katie Holmes and Suri. Coons does not know who that is.

ep-658.speaker: chris coons
ep-658.utterance: That's great.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: I don't know how to answer that question.

ep-658.speaker: chris coons
ep-658.utterance: Bring her on in.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: She's the actress who was--

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Used to be married to Tom Cruise.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: --married to Tom Cruise.

ep-658.speaker: chris coons
ep-658.utterance: That's great. I've heard of him. I am so useless.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Come in, Katie.

ep-658.speaker: katie holmes
ep-658.utterance: Hi, you.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Good to see you.

ep-658.speaker: katie holmes
ep-658.utterance: Thank you.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: To be fair, neither of the senators seems to know who any of these people are-- except Di Niro. Everyone wants a picture with the senators.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Soon Coons and Flake are rushed towards the stage, continuing to be mobbed by the Hollywood resistance. Darren Aronofsky yells to them, "I'm a film maker. I made Black Swan."

ep-658.speaker: darren aronofsky
ep-658.utterance: I'm a filmmaker. I made Black Swan. Thank you for everything you're doing right now.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: I go around to the front, to see how thousands of non-famous New Yorkers are receiving this still-Republican senator.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Thanks to all of you global citizens--

ep-658.speaker: woman
ep-658.utterance: Fuck you!

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: --who have contacted us--

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: That's a real New York "fuck you." The call for bipartisanship is drowned out by calls for Cardi B.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: We're standing here, united for democracy.

ep-658.speaker: crowd
ep-658.utterance: Cardi! Cardi!

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: As soon as they're offstage, though, the star treatment starts again. The Reverend Al Sharpton catches him, like we're on a red carpet.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Hey, Al.

ep-658.speaker: al sharpton
ep-658.utterance: Senator Coons just called you a hero.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Naw. Naw, he's the guy. He's the guy. He's the guy.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: "Do you think we can bring this country together?" Al says. It's like a left-wing farce at this point. Random bit players keep popping out to cast liberal spells. Chris Martin, from Coldplay, gives Flake a magic pin of some sort to keep in his pocket.

ep-658.speaker: chris martin
ep-658.utterance: Oh, yeah. Jeff, here. Take this. Put it in your pocket in times of trouble. All right?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Thank you. Oh!

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Flake drops it. Chris Martin leaves. We have a moment to sit down.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: What is it like?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: It's intimidating.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Was it?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Yeah. Well I mean, it's not something you know. This is different than a conference on Social Security reform or-- you know?

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: It's not the Cato Institute.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Different. No, it's not. [LAUGHTER] Far from.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: What's it like having people like Robert Di Niro and John Legend be like, you're a hero? For a week-long FBI investigation?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Well, it'll last a week, too. My next vote, for Kavanaugh or for something they don't like, and I'm a pariah again.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: [LAUGHTER] So you enjoy it for a week.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Do you think they know you're still a Republican?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: You know, I think probably so. You enjoy it while you can.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Jeff Flake's had a rough few years. They hate him on the right, and he keeps disappointing the left. It feels good, for once, to be popular.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Are you happy? Do you like it?

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Oh, yeah. Every politician does. We like it. Politicians-- we feed on it. That's a-- whether we admit it or not.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: And then it happens, just like he predicted. After seven days of being treated as a Democrat-- or at least a Republican defector-- Flake comes home to the GOP. On Thursday, the FBI releases the report that he called for. On Friday, Flake announced his decision. He's a yes on Kavanaugh. I reached Chris Coons that afternoon.

ep-658.speaker: chris coons
ep-658.utterance: Look, Jeff and I both went to the same place, and read the same report. And I appreciate his friendship. We are viewing this through a different lens. Jeff is a conservative senator. He has always wanted a conservative on the Supreme Court. I am not, and I don't.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Coons thought the FBI report was a disgrace, basically. They didn't follow up on any leads, he said. It was not the investigation he had asked for last week. He was mad. Frustrated. Kept going off the record and raging. He would not tell me about his conversations with Jeff Flake after they both read the FBI report.

ep-658.speaker: chris coons
ep-658.utterance: I'm really trying not to either put words in his mouth or criticize him, because-- I am restraining myself from saying something that is not appropriate here.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: As soon as Flake voted Friday, he fled the Capitol. I talked to him in the car. People are mad at you again, I said. Well, that's how it goes, he said. Why did you vote yes, I asked him? Presumption of innocence, he told me, over and over. He was satisfied with the FBI report.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: Do you feel better now? You're kind of back among your people. You had kind of a week with the Democrats celebrating you, but you're back among your people.

ep-658.speaker: jeff flake
ep-658.utterance: Do I have people? I guess so. I am a man, temporarily, without a party.

ep-658.speaker: zoe chace
ep-658.utterance: There is no bipartisan right now. There is no aisle to stand in the middle of. To quote a film that Robert Di Niro was not in, but kind of-- "Don't ever take sides with anyone against the family. Ever."
